title: Report: Hazing does not appear widespread in sampling of Maryland high schools
text:
Hazing, bullying and sexual assault do not appear to be widespread in the high school sports and extracurricular programs of a suburban Maryland school system, according to a report that examined a sampling of campuses following a violent locker room attack.

But the analysis released Monday by Montgomery County school officials said students do not have a good grasp of what constitutes hazing, how to respond to it or if they should report it.

The review, done by the law firm WilmerHale, did not specifically examine the events of Oct. 31, 2018, at Damascus High School, where members of the junior varsity football team allegedly used a broomstick to sexually assault four teammates.

It was described as a wider look at school culture, supervision and incident reporting practices within athletic and extracurricular activity programs at Damascus and several other Montgomery County high schools.

The report’s authors acknowledged that no comprehensive, historical review was done of unreported incidents and that no districtwide survey was conducted for the analysis.

Five high schools were examined in the sprawling suburban system, which has 25 high schools and is the largest in Maryland.

Still, it said, “the few extracurricular-associated hazing and bullying incidents of which we became aware appeared to be isolated events, rather than part of a larger, continuing pattern.”

While there were few major revelations in the 16-page document, it contained pointed findings on several issues.

Some coaches and sponsors were not aware of the school system’s agreement with police to report certain incidents directly to law enforcement. The coaches and activity sponsors said they personally would call police for “very serious” incidents, such as child sexual abuse, but would report those viewed as less serious to school administrators.

Before the Damascus attack, some coaches were not always present while players used locker rooms and team rooms, or did not consistently lock the facilities when they were not being used, the report said.

The examination noted a previous instance of alleged misconduct by football players, at Seneca Valley High School — reported by The Washington Post — and vaguely referred to other incidents in athletics and extracurricular activities but gave no detail, saying those matters were “relatively minor and were quickly and appropriately addressed.”

[Hazing incident reported at another Maryland high school, officials say]

At Damascus High, the incident left a football-proud community reeling and raised broader questions districtwide about how students are supervised and how incidents are reported to police.

The Post reported that the school waited more than 12 hours to bring in law enforcement and launched its own in-house investigation first.

[A football locker room, a broomstick and a sex assault case roil a school]

No coaches were in the locker room over a 25-minute stretch before practice, school officials have said, during which the relatively brief but violent attacks unfolded. All of the students involved were 14 or 15 years old at the time.

In November, four of the players were each charged as adults with one count of first-degree rape and three counts of attempted, first-degree rape, according to court records. The cases were later transferred to juvenile court, where each teen pleaded to being involved in the attacks, according to court hearings held largely behind closed doors in Montgomery County.

Because the juvenile hearings were not open for the full proceedings, the exact role each student played remains unclear, as does the punishment or rehabilitation recommendations each received.

The report released Monday said the school system had generally fostered a positive culture around athletics and extracurricular activities, but it also noted that administrators and coaches set the tone.

It pointed to a “supervision gap” between the end of the school day and the beginning of sports practice, when a junior varsity or freshman team may have to wait for its turn on a field or court. Many students don’t have the means to go home and come back to school again. Supervision often falls on building services staff, it said.

Recent efforts to require coaches and sponsors to file written supervision plans have had “mixed results,” the study found, with variations in quality and complaints about feeling forced to craft plans that are unrealistic, given resource limitations.

Speaking to reporters Monday, Montgomery County schools Superintendent Jack Smith said the analysis marked a step forward.

“With all the work our external reviewers did, we have lots of things to think about and work on in our system,” he said.

Smith noted in a letter to the community Monday that the school system had already taken steps to improve and launched a student-athlete leadership council. In the next year, the district hopes to work with a national organization to become a leader in best practices in after-school safety and supervision, he said.

[Damascus High returns to football field, a year after sexual assault case consumed town]

Thomas M. DeGonia, an attorney representing the family of one of the victims, questioned the significance and breadth of the report.

“The school system is now saying there is currently no widespread culture of these kinds of problems,” DeGonia said. “Well, OK, but everyone has been talking about this for a year. What’s not answered is how did things at Damascus devolve to the point where there was a brutal sexual assault in a locker room by several players who didn’t think there was anything wrong with it?”

DeGonia called on the school system to be more transparent about what it discovered and what problems existed. That is part of what the public wants to know, the attorney said.

“What were the risks and dangers in October 2018 — at Damascus and anywhere else in the county?” DeGonia said.

The report looked at best practices and issued recommendations, including considering more security staffing after school or supervised spaces such as a study hall or media center. It urged improvements to training for administrators and coaches, and in programming for student athletes and extracurricular participants.

It said that while students know how to identify and respond to bullying, they have less awareness about hazing.

“This is partly due to the fact that a fine line separates innocuous bonding rituals and hazing; benign traditions can escalate quickly,” it said. “Because students did not have a clear definition of hazing, we also found that they were not sure how they would respond to it or if they should report such incidents.”

The report, which cost $250,000, was based on 29 interviews — with administrators, school staff members, coaches, parents and sponsors — along with student and staff focus-group discussions and a review of documents related to the Damascus attack, state and federal laws, and school system policies.

The law firm also examined school system reports on serious incidents, bullying and student discipline for the last four years at Damascus and four other high schools — Seneca Valley, Montgomery Blair, Walt Whitman and Walter Johnson.

[Outside investigation of Damascus High sexual assault case takes longer than expected]

The release of the report comes as a separate inquiry by prosecutors is expected to be complete in 30 to 60 days, according to Montgomery County State’s Attorney John McCarthy. That office has reviewed years of school system records and is examining whether earlier episodes unfolded at Damascus High similar to what happened last fall.

School officials also did their own personnel investigation, related to the Oct. 31 incident. A junior varsity coach and the athletic director at Damascus High no longer work for the school system. The principal moved into a central-office position, and the varsity coach remains in place.
